items.name: Ext.util.GroupCollection
items.text: A collection containing the result of applying grouping to the records in the store.

items.name: autoGroup
items.text: `true` to sort by the grouper

items.name: autoSort
items.text:
`true` to maintain sorted order when items
are added regardless of requested insertion point, or when an item mutation
results in a new sort position.

This does not affect a filtered Collection's reaction to mutations of the source
Collection. If sorters are present when the source Collection is mutated, this Collection's
sort order will always be maintained.

items.name: decoder
items.text:
A function that can convert newly added items to a proper type before being
added to this collection.

items.name: defaultSortDirection
items.text: The default sort direction to use if one is not specified.

items.name: extraKeys
filters
grouper
groups
items.text: The collection of to hold each group container. This collection is created and removed dynamically based on grouper. Application code should only need to call `getGroups` to retrieve the collection and not `setGroups`.

items.name: keyFn
items.text: A function to retrieve the key of an item in the collection. If provided, this replaces the default getKey method. The default getKey method handles items that have either an "id" or "_id" property or failing that a getId method to call.

items.name: listeners
multiSortLimit
items.text: The maximum number of sorters which may be applied to this Sortable when using the "multi" insertion position when adding sorters. New sorters added using the "multi" insertion position are inserted at the top of the sorters list becoming the new primary sort key. If the sorters collection has grown to longer then **multiSortLimit**, then the it is trimmed.

items.name: rootProperty
items.text: The root property to use for aggregation, filtering and sorting. By default this is null but when containing things like Ext.data.Model this config would likely be set to "data" so that property names are applied to the fields of each record.

items.name: sorters
items.text: Array of Ext.util.Sorter for this collection. At the time a collection is created the sorters can be specified as a unit. After that time the normal `setSorters` method can be also be given a set of replacement sorters. Individual sorters can be specified as an Ext.util.Sorter instance, a config object for Ext.util.Sorter or simply the name of a property by which to sort. An alternative way to extend the sorters is to call the `sort` method and pass a property or sorter config to add to the sorters. For fine grain control of the sorters collection, call getSorters to return the Ext.util.Collection instance that holds this collection's sorters. var collection = new Ext.util.Collection(); var sorters = collection.getSorters(); // an Ext.util.SorterCollection sorters.add('name'); //... sorters.remove('name'); Any changes to the sorters collection will cause this collection to adjust its items accordingly (if autoSort is `true`).

items.name: source
items.text: The base `Collection`. This collection contains the items to which filters are applied to populate this collection. In this configuration, only the root source collection can have items truly added or removed.

items.name: trackGroups
items.text: `true` to track individual groups in a Ext.util.GroupCollection

items.name: add
items.text: Fires after items have been added to the collection. All event-add and event-remove events occur between event-beginupdate and event-endupdate events so it is best to do only the minimal amount of work in response to these events and move the more expensive side-effects to an endupdate listener.

items.name: collection
items.text: The collection being modified.

items.name: details
items.text: An object describing the addition.

items.name: at
items.text: The index in the collection where the add occurred.

items.name: atItem
items.text: The item after which the new items were inserted or null if at the beginning of the collection.

items.name: items
items.text: The items that are now added to the collection.

items.name: keys
items.text: If available this array holds the keys (extracted by getKey) for each item in the items array.

items.name: next
items.text: If more event-add events are in queue to be delivered this is a reference to the `details` instance for the next event-add event. This will only be the case when the collection is sorted as the new items often need to be inserted at multiple locations to maintain the sort. In this case, all of the new items have already been added not just those described by the first event-add event.

items.name: replaced
items.text: If this addition has a corresponding set of event-remove events this reference holds the `details` object for the first `remove` event. That `details` object may have a `next` property if there are multiple associated `remove` events.

items.name: beforeitemchange
items.text: This event fires before an item change is reflected in the collection. This event is always followed by an itemchange event and, depending on the change, possibly an `add`, `remove` and/or updatekey event.

items.name: collection
items.text: The collection being modified.

items.name: details
items.text: An object describing the change.

items.name: item
items.text: The item that has changed.

items.name: key
items.text: The key of the item that has changed.

items.name: filterChanged
items.text:
This is `true` if the filter status of the
`item` has changed. That is, the item was previously filtered out and is no longer
or the opposite.

items.name: keyChanged
items.text: This is `true` if the item has changed keys. If so, check `oldKey` for the old key. An updatekey event will follow.

items.name: indexChanged
items.text:
This is `true` if the item needs to move to
a new index in the collection due to sorting. The index can be seen in `index`.
The old index is in `oldIndex`.

items.name: modified
items.text:
If known this property holds the array of names
of the modified properties of the item.

items.name: filtered
items.text:
This value is `true` if the item will be filtered
out of the collection.

items.name: index
items.text:
The new index in the collection for the item if
the item is being moved (see `indexChanged`). If the item is being removed due to
filtering, this will be -1.

items.name: oldIndex
items.text:
The old index in the collection for the item if
the item is being moved (see `indexChanged`). If the item was being removed due to
filtering, this will be -1.

items.name: oldKey
items.text:
The old key for the `item` if the item's key has
changed (see `keyChanged`).

items.name: wasFiltered
items.text:
This value is `true` if the item was filtered
out of the collection.

items.name: beforesort
items.text: This event fires before the contents of the collection have been sorted.

items.name: collection
items.text: The collection being sorted.

items.name: sorters
items.text: Array of sorters applied to the Collection.

items.name: beginupdate
items.text: Fired before changes are made to the collection. This event fires when the beginUpdate method is called and the counter it manages transitions from 0 to 1. All event-add and event-remove events occur between event-beginupdate and event-endupdate events so it is best to do only the minimal amount of work in response to these events and move the more expensive side-effects to an endupdate listener.

items.name: collection
items.text: The collection being modified.

items.name: endupdate
items.text: Fired after changes are made to the collection. This event fires when the endUpdate method is called and the counter it manages transitions from 1 to 0. All event-add and event-remove events occur between event-beginupdate and event-endupdate events so it is best to do only the minimal amount of work in response to these events and move the more expensive side-effects to an endupdate listener.

items.name: collection
items.text: The collection being modified.

items.name: itemchange
items.text: This event fires after an item change is reflected in the collection. This event always follows a beforeitemchange event and its corresponding `add`, `remove` and/or updatekey events.

items.name: collection
items.text: The collection being modified.

items.name: details
items.text: An object describing the change.

items.name: item
items.text: The item that has changed.

items.name: key
items.text: The key of the item that has changed.

items.name: filterChanged
items.text:
This is `true` if the filter status of the
`item` has changed. That is, the item was previously filtered out and is no longer
or the opposite.

items.name: keyChanged
items.text: This is `true` if the item has changed keys. If so, check `oldKey` for the old key. An updatekey event will have been sent.

items.name: indexChanged
items.text:
This is `true` if the item was moved to a
new index in the collection due to sorting. The index can be seen in `index`.
The old index is in `oldIndex`.

items.name: modified
items.text:
If known this property holds the array of names
of the modified properties of the item.

items.name: filtered
items.text:
This value is `true` if the item is filtered
out of the collection.

items.name: index
items.text:
The new index in the collection for the item if
the item has been moved (see `indexChanged`). If the item is removed due to
filtering, this will be -1.

items.name: oldIndex
items.text:
The old index in the collection for the item if
the item has been moved (see `indexChanged`). If the item was being removed due to
filtering, this will be -1.

items.name: oldKey
items.text:
The old key for the `item` if the item's key has
changed (see `keyChanged`).

items.name: wasFiltered
items.text:
This value is `true` if the item was filtered
out of the collection.

items.name: refresh
items.text:
This event fires when the collection has changed entirely. This event is fired in
cases where the collection's filter is updated or the items are sorted. While the
items previously in the collection may remain the same, the order at a minimum has
changed in ways that cannot be simply translated to other events.

items.name: collection
items.text: The collection being modified.

items.name: remove
items.text: Fires after items have been removed from the collection. Some properties of this object may not be present if calculating them is deemed too expensive. These are marked as "optional". All event-add and event-remove events occur between event-beginupdate and event-endupdate events so it is best to do only the minimal amount of work in response to these events and move the more expensive side-effects to an endupdate listener.

items.name: collection
items.text: The collection being modified.

items.name: details
items.text: An object describing the removal.

items.name: at
items.text: The index in the collection where the removal occurred.

items.name: items
items.text: The items that are now removed from the collection.

items.name: keys
items.text: If available this array holds the keys (extracted by getKey) for each item in the items array.

items.name: map
items.text: If available this is a map keyed by the key of each item in the items array. This will often contain all of the items being removed and not just the items in the range described by this event. The value held in this map is the item.

items.name: next
items.text: If more event-remove events are in queue to be delivered this is a reference to the `details` instance for the next remove event.

items.name: replacement
items.text: If this removal has a corresponding event-add taking place this reference holds the `details` object for that `add` event. If the collection is sorted, the new items are pre-sorted but the `at` property for the `replacement` will **not** be correct. The new items will be added in one or more chunks at their proper index.

items.name: sort
items.text: This event fires after the contents of the collection have been sorted.

items.name: collection
items.text: The collection being sorted.

items.name: updatekey
items.text: Fires after the key for an item has changed.

items.name: collection
items.text: The collection being modified.

items.name: details
items.text: An object describing the update.

items.name: item
items.text: The item whose key has changed.

items.name: newKey
items.text: The new key for the `item`.

items.name: oldKey
items.text: The old key for the `item`.

items.name: _addDeclaredListeners
items.text: Adds declarative listeners as nested arrays of listener objects.
`true` if any listeners were added

items.name: add
item
items.text: The item or items to add.
The item or items added.

items.name: addAfterListener
items.text: Alias for onAfter.

items.name: addBeforeListener
items.text: Alias for onBefore.

items.name: addListener
eventName
items.text:
The name of the event to listen for.
May also be an object who's property names are event names.

items.name: fn
items.text: The method the event invokes or the *name* of the method within the specified `scope`. Will be called with arguments given to Ext.util.Observable#fireEvent plus the `options` parameter described below.

items.name: scope
items.text:
The scope (`this` reference) in which the handler function is
executed. **If omitted, defaults to the object which fired the event.**

items.name: options
items.text:
An object containing handler configuration.

**Note:** The options object will also be passed as the last argument to every
event handler.

This object may contain any of the following properties:

items.name: scope
items.text:
The scope (`this` reference) in which the handler function is executed. **If omitted,
  defaults to the object which fired the event.**

items.name: delay
items.text:
The number of milliseconds to delay the invocation of the handler after the event
  fires.

items.name: single
items.text:
True to add a handler to handle just the next firing of the event, and then remove
  itself.

items.name: buffer
items.text: Causes the handler to be scheduled to run in an Ext.util.DelayedTask delayed by the specified number of milliseconds. If the event fires again within that time, the original handler is _not_ invoked, but the new handler is scheduled in its place.

items.name: onFrame
items.text: Causes the handler to be scheduled to run at the next Ext.Function#requestAnimationFrame. If the event fires again before that time, the handler is not rescheduled - the handler will only be called once when the next animation frame is fired, with the last set of arguments passed.

items.name: target
items.text:
Only call the handler if the event was fired on the target Observable, _not_ if the
  event was bubbled up from a child Observable.

items.name: element
items.text: **This option is only valid for listeners bound to Ext.Component.** The name of a Component property which references an Ext.dom.Element to add a listener to. This option is useful during Component construction to add DOM event listeners to elements of Ext.Component which will exist only after the Component is rendered. For example, to add a click listener to a Panel's body: var panel = new Ext.panel.Panel({ title: 'The title', listeners: { click: this.handlePanelClick, element: 'body' } }); In order to remove listeners attached using the element, you'll need to reference the element itself as seen below. panel.body.un(...)

items.name: delegate
items.text:
A simple selector to filter the event target or look for a descendant of the target.

  The "delegate" option is only available on Ext.dom.Element instances (or
  when attaching a listener to a Ext.dom.Element via a Component using the
  element option).

  See the *delegate* example below.

items.name: stopPropagation
items.text: **This option is only valid for listeners bound to Ext.dom.Element.** `true` to call Ext.event.Event#stopPropagation on the event object before firing the handler.

items.name: preventDefault
items.text: **This option is only valid for listeners bound to Ext.dom.Element.** `true` to call Ext.event.Event#preventDefault on the event object before firing the handler.

items.name: stopEvent
items.text: **This option is only valid for listeners bound to Ext.dom.Element.** `true` to call Ext.event.Event#stopEvent on the event object before firing the handler.

items.name: args
items.text: Optional arguments to pass to the handler function. Any additional arguments passed to Ext.util.Observable#fireEvent will be appended to these arguments.

items.name: destroyable
items.text: When specified as `true`, the function returns a `destroyable` object. An object which implements the destroy method which removes all listeners added in this call. This syntax can be a helpful shortcut to using un; particularly when removing multiple listeners. *NOTE* - not compatible when using the _element_ option. See un for the proper syntax for removing listeners added using the _element_ config.

items.name: priority
items.text:
An optional numeric priority that determines the order in which event handlers
  are run. Event handlers with no priority will be run as if they had a priority
  of 0. Handlers with a higher priority will be prioritized to run sooner than
  those with a lower priority.  Negative numbers can be used to set a priority
  lower than the default. Internally, the framework uses a range of 1000 or
  greater, and -1000 or lesser for handlers that are intended to run before or
  after all others, so it is recommended to stay within the range of -999 to 999
  when setting the priority of event handlers in application-level code.
  A priority must be an integer to be valid.  Fractional values are reserved for
  internal framework use.

items.name: order
items.text:
A legacy option that is provided for backward compatibility.
  It is recommended to use the `priority` option instead.  Available options are:

  - `'before'`: equal to a priority of `100`
  - `'current'`: equal to a priority of `0` or default priority
  - `'after'`: equal to a priority of `-100`

items.name: order
addManagedListener
item
items.text: The item to which to add a listener/listeners.

items.name: ename
items.text: The event name, or an object containing event name properties.

items.name: fn
items.text:
(optional) If the `ename` parameter was an event
name, this is the handler function or the name of a method on the specified
`scope`.

items.name: scope
items.text:
(optional) If the `ename` parameter was an event name, this is the scope (`this` reference)
in which the handler function is executed.

items.name: options
items.text: (optional) If the `ename` parameter was an event name, this is the Ext.util.Observable#addListener options.

items.name: addObserver
items.text: Adds an observing object to this collection. Observers are given first view of all events that we may fire. For any event an observer may implement a method whose name starts with "onCollection" to receive the event. The event-add event for example would be passed to `"onCollectionAdd"`. The only restriction to observers is that they are not allowed to add or remove observers from inside these methods.

items.name: observer
items.text: The observer instance.

items.name: aggregate
property
items.text: The name of the property to aggregate from each item.

items.name: operation
items.text: The operation to perform.

items.name: items
items.text:
The items on which the `operation` function is to
operate.

items.name: values
items.text:
The values on which the `operation` function is to
operate.

items.name: begin
items.text: The index of the first item in items to include in the aggregation.

items.name: end
items.text: The index at which to stop aggregating items. The item at this index will *not* be included in the aggregation.

items.name: scope
items.text:
The `this` pointer to use if `operation` is a function.
Defaults to this collection.

items.name: aggregateByGroup
items.text: See aggregate. The functionality is the same, however the aggregates are provided per group. Assumes this collection has an active grouper.

items.name: property
items.text: The name of the property to aggregate from each item.

items.name: operation
items.text: The operation to perform.

items.name: items
items.text:
The items on which the `operation` function is to
operate.

items.name: values
items.text:
The values on which the `operation` function is to
operate.

items.name: scope
items.text:
The `this` pointer to use if `operation` is a function.
Defaults to this collection.

items.name: aggregateGroups
items.text: Aggregates a set of groups.

items.name: groups
items.text: The groups

items.name: property
items.text: The name of the property to aggregate from each item.

items.name: operation
items.text: The operation to perform.

items.name: values
items.text:
The values on which the `operation` function is to
operate.

items.name: items
items.text:
The items on which the `operation` function is to
operate.

items.name: index
items.text: The index in items at which the `operation` function is to start. The `values.length` indicates the number of items involved.

items.name: scope
items.text:
The `this` pointer to use if `operation` is a function.
Defaults to this collection.

items.name: aggregateItems
items.text: Returns the result of the specified aggregation operation against the given items. For details see aggregate.

items.name: items
items.text: The items to aggregate.

items.name: property
items.text: The name of the property to aggregate from each item.

items.name: operation
items.text: The operation to perform.

items.name: items
items.text:
The items on which the `operation` function is to
operate.

items.name: values
items.text:
The values on which the `operation` function is to
operate.

items.name: begin
items.text: The index of the first item in items to include in the aggregation.

items.name: end
items.text: The index at which to stop aggregating items. The item at this index will *not* be included in the aggregation.

items.name: scope
items.text:
The `this` pointer to use if `operation` is a function.
Defaults to this collection.

items.name: average
items.text: Averages property values from some or all of the items in this collection.

items.name: property
items.text: The name of the property to average from each item.

items.name: begin
items.text: The index of the first item to include in the average.

items.name: end
items.text: The index at which to stop averaging items. The item at this index will *not* be included in the average.

The result of averaging the specified property from the indicated
items.

items.name: averageByGroup
items.text: See average. The result is partitioned by group.

items.name: property
items.text: The name of the property to average from each item.
The result of average, partitioned by group. See aggregateByGroup.

items.name: beginUpdate
bounds
items.text:
Determines the minimum and maximum values for the specified property over some or
all of the items in this collection.

items.name: property
items.text: The name of the property from each item.

items.name: begin
items.text: The index of the first item to include in the bounds.

items.name: end
items.text: The index at which to stop in items. The item at this index will *not* be included in the bounds.

An array `[min, max]` with the minimum and maximum of the specified
property.

items.name: boundsByGroup
items.text: See bounds. The result is partitioned by group.

items.name: property
items.text: The name of the property from each item.
The result of bounds, partitioned by group. See aggregateByGroup.

items.name: clear
items.text: Removes all items from the collection. This is similar to removeAll except that removeAll fire events to inform listeners. This means that this method should be called only when you are sure there are no listeners.

items.name: clearListeners
items.text: Removes all listeners for this object including the managed listeners

items.name: clearManagedListeners
items.text: Removes all managed listeners for this object.

items.name: clone
items.text: Creates a shallow copy of this collection

items.name: collect
items.text: Collects unique values of a particular property in this Collection.

items.name: property
items.text: The property to collect on

items.name: root
items.text:
(optional) 'root' property to extract the first argument from. This is used mainly when
summing fields in records, where the fields are all stored inside the 'data' object

items.name: allowNull
items.text: Pass `true` to include null, undefined or empty string values.
The unique values

items.name: constructor
items.text: Creates new Object.

items.name: value
items.text: The value to wrap.

items.name: contains
items.text: Returns true if the collection contains the passed Object as an item.

items.name: item
items.text: The Object to look for in the collection.
`true` if the collection contains the Object as an item.

items.name: containsKey
items.text: Returns true if the collection contains the passed Object as a key.

items.name: key
items.text: The key to look for in the collection.
True if the collection contains the Object as a key.

items.name: count
items.text: Determines the number of items in the collection.
The number of items.

items.name: countByGroup
items.text: See count. The result is partitioned by group.
The result of count, partitioned by group. See aggregateByGroup.

items.name: createFiltered
property
items.text: A property on your objects, an array of Ext.util.Filter objects or a filter function.

items.name: value
items.text: If `property` is a function, this argument is the "scope" (or "this" pointer) for the function. Otherwise this is either a RegExp to test property values or the value with which to compare.

items.name: anyMatch
items.text:
True to match any part of the string, not just
the beginning.

items.name: caseSensitive
items.text: True for case sensitive comparison.

items.name: exactMatch
items.text: `true` to force exact match (^ and $ characters added to the regex).
The new, filtered collection.

items.name: createRelayer
items.text: Creates an event handling function which re-fires the event from this object as the passed event name.

items.name: newName
items.text: The name under which to re-fire the passed parameters.

items.name: beginEnd
items.text: (optional) The caller can specify on which indices to slice.

items.name: decodeItems
args
items.text: The arguments object from the caller.

items.name: index
items.text: The index in `args` (the caller's arguments) of items.
The array of items on which to operate.

items.name: decodeRemoveItems
items.text: This method is an alias for decodeItems but is called when items are being removed. If a decoder is provided it may be necessary to also override this method to achieve symmetry between adding and removing items. This is the case for `Ext.util.FilterCollection' and `Ext.util.SorterCollection' for example.

items.name: destroy
items.text: Destroys this collection. This is only necessary if this collection uses a source collection as that relationship will keep a reference from the source to this collection and potentially leak memory.

items.name: doFireEvent
items.text: Continue to fire event.

items.name: each
items.text:
Executes the specified function once for every item in the collection. If the value
returned by `fn` is `false` the iteration stops. In all cases, the last value that
`fn` returns is returned by this method.

items.name: fn
items.text: The function to execute for each item.

items.name: item
items.text: The collection item.

items.name: index
items.text: The index of item.

items.name: len
items.text: Total length of collection.

items.name: scope
items.text:
The scope (`this` reference) in which the function
is executed. Defaults to this collection.

items.name: eachKey
items.text:
Executes the specified function once for every key in the collection, passing each
key, and its associated item as the first two parameters. If the value returned by
`fn` is `false` the iteration stops. In all cases, the last value that `fn` returns
is returned by this method.

items.name: fn
items.text: The function to execute for each item.

items.name: key
items.text: The key of collection item.

items.name: item
items.text: The collection item.

items.name: index
items.text: The index of item.

items.name: len
items.text: Total length of collection.

items.name: scope
items.text:
The scope (`this` reference) in which the function
is executed. Defaults to this collection.

items.name: enableBubble
eventNames
items.text: The event name to bubble, or an Array of event names.

items.name: endUpdate
items.text: This method is called after modifications are complete on a collection. For details see beginUpdate.

items.name: extremes
items.text:
Finds the items with the minimum and maximum for the specified property over some
or all of the items in this collection.

items.name: property
items.text: The name of the property from each item.

items.name: begin
items.text: The index of the first item to include.

items.name: end
items.text: The index at which to stop in items. The item at this index will *not* be included.

An array `[minItem, maxItem]` with the items that have the minimum
and maximum of the specified property.

items.name: extremesByGroup
items.text: See extremes. The result is partitioned by group.

items.name: property
items.text: The name of the property from each item.
The result of extremes, partitioned by group. See aggregateByGroup.

items.name: filterBy
items.text: Filter by a function. Returns a new collection that has been filtered. The passed function will be called with each object in the collection. If the function returns true, the value is included otherwise it is filtered.

items.name: fn
items.text: The function to be called.

items.name: item
items.text: The collection item.

items.name: key
items.text: The key of collection item.

items.name: scope
items.text: (optional) The scope (this reference) in which the function is executed. Defaults to this Collection.
The new filtered collection

items.name: find
items.text: Finds the first matching object in this collection by a specific property/value.

items.name: property
items.text: The name of a property on your objects.

items.name: value
items.text:
A string that the property values
should start with or a RegExp to test against the property.

items.name: start
items.text: The index to start searching at.

items.name: startsWith
items.text:
Pass `false` to allow a match start anywhere in
the string. By default the `value` will match only at the start of the string.

items.name: endsWith
items.text:
Pass `false` to allow the match to end before the
end of the string. By default the `value` will match only at the end of the string.

items.name: ignoreCase
items.text: Pass `false` to make the RegExp case sensitive (removes the 'i' flag).
The first item in the collection which matches the criteria or null if none was found.

items.name: findBy
items.text:
Returns the first item in the collection which elicits a true return value from the
passed selection function.

items.name: fn
items.text: The selection function to execute for each item.

items.name: item
items.text: The collection item.

items.name: key
items.text: The key of collection item.

items.name: scope
items.text:
The scope (`this` reference) in which the function
is executed. Defaults to this collection.

items.name: start
items.text: The index at which to start searching.

The first item in the collection which returned true from the selection
function, or null if none was found.

items.name: findIndex
items.text:
Finds the index of the first matching object in this collection by a specific
property/value.

items.name: property
items.text: The name of a property on your objects.

items.name: value
items.text:
A string that the property values
should start with or a RegExp to test against the property.

items.name: start
items.text: The index to start searching at.

items.name: startsWith
items.text:
Pass `false` to allow a match start anywhere in
the string. By default the `value` will match only at the start of the string.

items.name: endsWith
items.text:
Pass `false` to allow the match to end before the
end of the string. By default the `value` will match only at the end of the string.

items.name: ignoreCase
items.text: Pass `false` to make the RegExp case sensitive (removes the 'i' flag).
The matched index or -1 if not found.

items.name: findIndexBy
items.text:
Find the index of the first matching object in this collection by a function.
If the function returns `true` it is considered a match.

items.name: fn
items.text: The function to be called.

items.name: item
items.text: The collection item.

items.name: key
items.text: The key of collection item.

items.name: scope
items.text:
The scope (`this` reference) in which the function
is executed. Defaults to this collection.

items.name: start
items.text: The index at which to start searching.
The matched index or -1

items.name: fireAction
items.text: Fires the specified event with the passed parameters and executes a function (action). By default, the action function will be executed after any "before" event handlers (as specified using the `order` option of Ext.util.Observable#addListener), but before any other handlers are fired. This gives the "before" handlers an opportunity to cancel the event by returning `false`, and prevent the action function from being called. The action can also be configured to run after normal handlers, but before any "after" handlers (as specified using the `order` event option) by passing `'after'` as the `order` parameter. This configuration gives any event handlers except for "after" handlers the opportunity to cancel the event and prevent the action function from being called.

items.name: eventName
items.text: The name of the event to fire.

items.name: args
items.text: Arguments to pass to handlers and to the action function.

items.name: fn
items.text: The action function.

items.name: scope
items.text:
The scope (`this` reference) in which the handler function is
executed. **If omitted, defaults to the object which fired the event.**

items.name: options
items.text: Event options for the action function. Accepts any of the options of Ext.util.Observable#addListener

items.name: order
items.text: The order to call the action function relative too the event handlers (`'before'` or `'after'`). Note that this option is simply used to sort the action function relative to the event handlers by "priority". An order of `'before'` is equivalent to a priority of `99.5`, while an order of `'after'` is equivalent to a priority of `-99.5`. See the `priority` option of Ext.util.Observable#addListener for more details.

items.name: fireEvent
items.text: Fires the specified event with the passed parameters (minus the event name, plus the `options` object passed to Ext.util.Observable#addListener). An event may be set to bubble up an Observable parent hierarchy (See Ext.Component#getBubbleTarget) by calling enableBubble.

items.name: eventName
items.text: The name of the event to fire.

items.name: args
items.text: Variable number of parameters are passed to handlers.
returns false if any of the handlers return false otherwise it returns true.

items.name: fireEventArgs
items.text: Fires the specified event with the passed parameter list. An event may be set to bubble up an Observable parent hierarchy (See Ext.Component#getBubbleTarget) by calling enableBubble.

items.name: eventName
items.text: The name of the event to fire.

items.name: args
items.text: An array of parameters which are passed to handlers.
returns false if any of the handlers return false otherwise it returns true.

items.name: fireEventedAction
items.text:
Fires the specified event with the passed parameters and executes a function (action).
Evented Actions will automatically dispatch a 'before' event passing. This event will
be given a special controller that allows for pausing/resuming of the event flow.

By pausing the controller the updater and events will not run until resumed. Pausing,
however, will not stop the processing of any other before events.

items.name: eventName
items.text: The name of the event to fire.

items.name: args
items.text: Arguments to pass to handlers and to the action function.

items.name: fn
items.text: The action function.

items.name: scope
items.text:
The scope (`this` reference) in which the handler function is
executed. **If omitted, defaults to the object which fired the event.**

items.name: fnArgs
items.text:
Optional arguments for the action `fn`. If not
given, the normal `args` will be used to call `fn`. If `false` is passed, the
`args` are used but if the first argument is this instance it will be removed
from the args passed to the action function.

items.name: first
items.text: Returns the first item in the collection.

items.name: grouped
items.text: `true` to extract the first item in each group. Only applies if a grouper is active in the collection.
The first item in the collection. If the grouped parameter is passed, see aggregateByGroup for information on the return type.

items.name: get
items.text: Returns the item associated with the passed key.

items.name: key
items.text: The key of the item.
The item associated with the passed key.

items.name: getAt
items.text: Returns the item at the specified index.

items.name: index
items.text: The index of the item.
The item at the specified index.

items.name: getBubbleParent
items.text: Gets the bubbling parent for an Observable
The bubble parent. null is returned if no bubble target exists

items.name: getByKey
items.text: Returns the item associated with the passed key.

items.name: key
items.text: The key of the item.
The item associated with the passed key.

items.name: getCount
items.text: Returns the number of items in the collection.
the number of items in the collection.

items.name: getFilterFn
items.text: Returns the filter function.
sortFn The sort function.

items.name: getFilters
items.text: Returns the Ext.util.FilterCollection. Unless `autoCreate` is explicitly passed as `false` this collection will be automatically created if it does not yet exist.

items.name: autoCreate
items.text: Pass `false` to disable auto-creation of the collection.
The collection of filters.

items.name: getId
items.text: Retrieves the id of this component. Will autogenerate an id if one has not already been set.
id

items.name: getIndices
items.text:
Returns the map of key to index for all items in this collection. This method will
lazily populate this map on request. This map is maintained when doing so does not
involve too much overhead. When this threshold is cross, the index map is discarded
and must be rebuilt by calling this method.

items.name: getKey
item
items.text: The item.
The key for the passed item.

items.name: getRange
items.text: Returns a range of items in this collection

items.name: begin
items.text: The index of the first item to get.

items.name: end
items.text: The ending index. The item at this index is *not* included.
An array of items

items.name: getSorters
items.text: Returns the Ext.util.SorterCollection. Unless `autoCreate` is explicitly passed as `false` this collection will be automatically created if it does not yet exist.

items.name: autoCreate
items.text: Pass `false` to disable auto-creation of the collection.
The collection of sorters.

items.name: getSortFn
items.text: Returns an up to date sort function.
The sort function.

items.name: getSource
items.text: Returns all unfiltered items in the Collection when the Collection has been filtered. Returns null when the Collection is not filtered.
items All unfiltered items (or null when the Collection is not filtered)

items.name: getValues
items.text: Returns an array of values for the specified (sub) property. For example, to get an array of "name" properties from a collection of records (of Ext.data.Model objects): var names = collection.getValues('name', 'data');

items.name: property
items.text: The property to collect on

items.name: root
items.text:
'root' property to extract the first argument from. This is
used mainly when operating on fields in records, where the fields are all stored
inside the 'data' object.
The values.

items.name: start
items.text: The index of the first item to include.

items.name: end
items.text:
The index at which to stop getting values. The value of this
item is *not* included.

items.name: hasListener
items.text:
Checks to see if this object has any listeners for a specified event, or whether the event bubbles. The answer
indicates whether the event needs firing or not.

items.name: eventName
items.text: The name of the event to check for
`true` if the event is being listened for or bubbles, else `false`

items.name: hasOwnProperty
prop
items.text: The name of the property to test.

Returns true if object contains specified property; else
returns false.

items.name: indexOf
items.text: Returns index within the collection of the passed Object.

items.name: item
items.text: The item to find.
The index of the item or -1 if not found.

items.name: indexOfKey
items.text: Returns index within the collection of the passed key.

items.name: key
items.text: The key to find.
The index of the item or -1 if not found.

items.name: insert
items.text:
Inserts one or more items to the collection. The `index` value is the position at
which the first item will be placed. The items starting at that position will be
shifted to make room.

items.name: index
items.text: The index at which to insert the item(s).

items.name: item
items.text: The item or items to add.
The item or items added.

items.name: isItemFiltered
items.text:
This method can be used to conveniently test whether an individual item would be
removed due to the current filter.

items.name: item
items.text: The item to test.

The value `true` if the item would be "removed" from the
collection due to filters or `false` otherwise.

items.name: isPrototypeOf
prototype
items.text:
an object to be tested against each link in the prototype chain of the
*object* argument

items.name: object
items.text: the object whose prototype chain will be searched
Returns true if object is a prototype and false if not.

items.name: isSuspended
items.text: Checks if all events, or a specific event, is suspended.

items.name: event
items.text: The name of the specific event to check
`true` if events are suspended

items.name: itemChanged
items.text: This method should be called when an item in this collection has been modified. If the collection is sorted or filtered the result of modifying an item needs to be reflected in the collection. If the item's key is also being modified, it is best to pass the `oldKey` to this same call rather than call updateKey separately.

items.name: item
items.text: The item that was modified.

items.name: modified
items.text: The names of the modified properties of the item.

items.name: oldKey
items.text: Passed if the item's key was also modified.

items.name: last
items.text: Returns the last item in the collection.

items.name: grouped
items.text: `true` to extract the first item in each group. Only applies if a grouper is active in the collection.
The last item in the collection. If the grouped parameter is passed, see aggregateByGroup for information on the return type.

items.name: max
items.text:
Determines the maximum value for the specified property over some or all of the
items in this collection.

items.name: property
items.text: The name of the property from each item.

items.name: begin
items.text: The index of the first item to include in the maximum.

items.name: end
items.text: The index at which to stop in items. The item at this index will *not* be included in the maximum.
The maximum of the specified property from the indicated items.

items.name: maxByGroup
items.text: See max. The result is partitioned by group.

items.name: property
items.text: The name of the property from each item.
The result of max, partitioned by group. See aggregateByGroup.

items.name: maxItem
items.text:
Finds the item with the maximum value for the specified property over some or all
of the items in this collection.

items.name: property
items.text: The name of the property from each item.

items.name: begin
items.text: The index of the first item to include in the maximum.

items.name: end
items.text: The index at which to stop in items. The item at this index will *not* be included in the maximum.

The item with the maximum of the specified property from the
indicated items.

items.name: maxItemByGroup
items.text: See maxItem. The result is partitioned by group.

items.name: property
items.text: The name of the property from each item.
The result of maxItem, partitioned by group. See aggregateByGroup.

items.name: min
items.text:
Determines the minimum value for the specified property over some or all of the
items in this collection.

items.name: property
items.text: The name of the property from each item.

items.name: begin
items.text: The index of the first item to include in the minimum.

items.name: end
items.text: The index at which to stop in items. The item at this index will *not* be included in the minimum.
The minimum of the specified property from the indicated items.

items.name: minByGroup
items.text: See min. The result is partitioned by group.

items.name: property
items.text: The name of the property from each item.
The result of min, partitioned by group. See aggregateByGroup.

items.name: minItem
items.text:
Finds the item with the minimum value for the specified property over some or all
of the items in this collection.

items.name: property
items.text: The name of the property from each item.

items.name: begin
items.text: The index of the first item to include in the minimum.

items.name: end
items.text: The index at which to stop in items. The item at this index will *not* be included in the minimum.

The item with the minimum of the specified property from the
indicated items.

items.name: minItemByGroup
items.text: See minItem. The result is partitioned by group.

items.name: property
items.text: The name of the property from each item.
The result of minItem, partitioned by group. See aggregateByGroup.

items.name: mon
items.text: Shorthand for addManagedListener.

items.name: mun
items.text: Shorthand for removeManagedListener.

items.name: notify
items.text: This method wraps all fired events and gives observers first view of the change.

items.name: eventName
items.text: The name of the event to fire.

items.name: args
items.text:
The event arguments. This collection instance is inserted at
the front of this array if there is any receiver for the notification.

items.name: onAfter
items.text: Appends an after-event handler. Same as Ext.util.Observable#addListener with `order` set to `'after'`.

items.name: eventName
items.text: The name of the event to listen for.

items.name: fn
items.text: The method the event invokes.

items.name: scope
items.text: The scope for `fn`.

items.name: options
items.text: An object containing handler configuration.

items.name: onBefore
items.text: Appends a before-event handler. Returning `false` from the handler will stop the event. Same as Ext.util.Observable#addListener with `order` set to `'before'`.

items.name: eventName
items.text: The name of the event to listen for.

items.name: fn
items.text: The method the event invokes.

items.name: scope
items.text: The scope for `fn`.

items.name: options
items.text: An object containing handler configuration.

items.name: onCollectionAdd
items.text: This method is called when items are added to the source collection. This is equivalent to the event-add event but is called before the `add` event is fired.

items.name: source
items.text: The source collection.

items.name: details
items.text: The `details` of the event-add event.

items.name: onCollectionBeforeItemChange
items.text: This method is called when an item is modified in the source collection. This is equivalent to the event-beforeitemchange event but is called before the beforeitemchange event is fired.

items.name: source
items.text: The source collection.

items.name: details
items.text: The `details` of the event-beforeitemchange event.

items.name: onCollectionBeginUpdate
items.text: This method is called when the source collection starts updating. This is equivalent to the event-beginupdate event but is called before the beginupdate event is fired.

items.name: source
items.text: The source collection.

items.name: onCollectionEndUpdate
items.text: This method is called when the source collection finishes updating. This is equivalent to the event-endupdate event but is called before the endupdate event is fired.

items.name: source
items.text: The source collection.

items.name: onCollectionItemChange
items.text: This method is called when an item is modified in the source collection. This is equivalent to the event-itemchange event but is called before the itemchange event is fired.

items.name: source
items.text: The source collection.

items.name: details
items.text: The `details` of the event-itemchange event.

items.name: onCollectionRefresh
items.text: This method is called when the source collection refreshes. This is equivalent to the event-refresh event but is called before the refresh event is fired.

items.name: source
items.text: The source collection.

items.name: onCollectionRemove
items.text: This method is called when items are removed from the source collection. This is equivalent to the event-remove event but is called before the `remove` event is fired.

items.name: source
items.text: The source collection.

items.name: details
items.text: The `details` of the `remove` event.

items.name: onCollectionSort
items.text: This method is called when the source collection is sorted. This is equivalent to the event-sort event but is called before the `sort` event is fired.

items.name: source
items.text: The source collection.

items.name: onCollectionUpdateKey
items.text: This method is called when key changes in the source collection. This is equivalent to the updatekey event but is called before the updatekey event is fired.

items.name: source
items.text: The source collection.

items.name: details
items.text: The `details` of the updatekey event.

items.name: onFilterChange
filters
items.text: The filters collection.

items.name: onSortChange
sorters
items.text: The sorters collection.

items.name: propertyIsEnumerable
prop
items.text: The name of the property to test.

If the object does not have the specified property, this
method returns false.

items.name: relayEvents
items.text:
Relays selected events from the specified Observable as if the events were fired by `this`.

For example if you are extending Grid, you might decide to forward some events from store.
So you can do this inside your initComponent:

    this.relayEvents(this.getStore(), ['load']);

The grid instance will then have an observable 'load' event which will be passed
the parameters of the store's load event and any function fired with the grid's
load event would have access to the grid using the this keyword (unless the event
is handled by a controller's control/listen event listener in which case 'this'
will be the controller rather than the grid).

items.name: origin
items.text: The Observable whose events this object is to relay.

items.name: events
items.text:
Array of event names to relay or an Object with key/value
pairs translating to ActualEventName/NewEventName respectively. For example:
    this.relayEvents(this, {add:'push', remove:'pop'});

Would now redispatch the add event of this as a push event and the remove event as a pop event.

items.name: prefix
remove
items.text: Remove an item from the collection.

items.name: item
items.text: The item or items to remove.
The number of items removed.

items.name: removeAfterListener
items.text: Alias for unAfter.

items.name: removeAll
items.text: Remove all items in the collection.
This object.

items.name: removeAt
items.text: Remove an item from a specified index in the collection.

items.name: index
items.text: The index within the collection of the item to remove.

items.name: count
items.text: The number of items to remove.
If count was 1 and the item was removed, that item is returned. Otherwise the number of items removed is returned.

items.name: removeBeforeListener
items.text: Alias for unBefore.

items.name: removeByKey
items.text: Removes the item associated with the passed key from the collection.

items.name: key
items.text: The key of the item to remove.

Only returned if removing at a specified key. The item removed or
`false` if no item was removed.

items.name: removeListener
items.text: Removes an event handler.

items.name: eventName
items.text: The type of event the handler was associated with.

items.name: fn
items.text: The handler to remove. **This must be a reference to the function passed into the Ext.util.Observable#addListener call.**

items.name: scope
removeManagedListener
items.text: Removes listeners that were added by the mon method.

items.name: item
items.text: The item from which to remove a listener/listeners.

items.name: ename
items.text: The event name, or an object containing event name properties.

items.name: fn
items.text: (optional) If the `ename` parameter was an event name, this is the handler function.

items.name: scope
items.text:
(optional) If the `ename` parameter was an event name, this is the scope (`this` reference)
in which the handler function is executed.

items.name: removeManagedListenerItem
items.text: Remove a single managed listener item

items.name: isClear
items.text: True if this is being called during a clear

items.name: managedListener
items.text:
The managed listener item
See removeManagedListener for other args

items.name: removeObserver
items.text: Removes an observing object to this collection. See addObserver for details.

items.name: observer
items.text: The observer instance.

items.name: replace
items.text: Replace an old entry with a new entry of the same key if the entry existed.

items.name: item
items.text: The item to insert.
inserted The item inserted.

items.name: replaceAll
items.text: Adds an item to the collection while removing any existing items. Similar to method-add.

items.name: item
items.text: The item or items to add.
The item or items added.

items.name: resolveListenerScope
items.text:
Gets the default scope for firing late bound events (string names with
no scope attached) at runtime.

items.name: defaultScope
items.text: The default scope to return if none is found.
The default event scope

items.name: resumeEvent
items.text: Resumes firing of the named event(s). After calling this method to resume events, the events will fire when requested to fire. **Note that if the suspendEvent method is called multiple times for a certain event, this converse method will have to be called the same number of times for it to resume firing.**

items.name: eventName
items.text: Multiple event names to resume.

items.name: resumeEvents
items.text: Resumes firing events (see suspendEvents). If events were suspended using the `queueSuspended` parameter, then all events fired during event suspension will be sent to any listeners now.

items.name: discardQueue
items.text: `true` to prevent any previously queued events from firing while we were suspended. See suspendEvents.

items.name: setListeners
items.text: An alias for Ext.util.Observable#addListener. In versions prior to 5.1, listeners had a generated setter which could be called to add listeners. In 5.1 the listeners config is not processed using the config system and has no generated setter, so this method is provided for backward compatibility. The preferred way of adding listeners is to use the on method.

items.name: listeners
items.text: The listeners

items.name: sort
property
items.text: Either the name of a property (such as a field of a Ext.data.Model in a `Store`), an array of configurations for Ext.util.Sorter instances or just a comparison function.

items.name: direction
items.text:
The direction by which to sort the data. This parameter
is only valid when `property` is a String, otherwise the second parameter is the
`mode`.

items.name: mode
items.text: Where to put new sorters in the collection. This should be one the following values: * `**replace**` : The new sorter(s) become the sole sorter set for this Sortable. This is the most useful call mode to programmatically sort by multiple fields. * `**prepend**` : The new sorters are inserted as the primary sorters. The sorter collection length must be controlled by the developer. * `**multi**` : Similar to `**prepend**` the new sorters are inserted at the front of the collection of sorters. Following the insertion, however, this mode trims the sorter collection to enforce the multiSortLimit config. This is useful for implementing intuitive "Sort by this" user interfaces. * `**append**` : The new sorters are added at the end of the collection.
This instance.

items.name: sortBy
items.text: Sorts the collection by a single sorter function

items.name: sorterFn
items.text: The function to sort by

items.name: sortData
items.text: This method will sort an array based on the currently configured sorters.

items.name: data
items.text: The array you want to have sorted.
The array you passed after it is sorted.

items.name: sortItems
items.text: Sorts the items of the collection using the supplied function. This should only be called for collections that have no sorters defined.

items.name: sortFn
items.text: The function by which to sort the items.

items.name: splice
items.text:
This method is basically the same as the JavaScript Array splice method.

Negative indexes are interpreted starting at the end of the collection. That is,
a value of -1 indicates the last item, or equivalent to `length - 1`.

items.name: index
items.text: The index at which to add or remove items.

items.name: toRemove
items.text:
The number of items to remove or an array of the
items to remove.

items.name: toAdd
items.text: The items to insert at the given `index`.

items.name: spliceMerge
items.text:
This method is what you might find in the core of a merge sort. We have an items
array that is sorted so we sort the newItems and merge the two sorted arrays. In
the general case, newItems will be no larger than all items so sorting it will be
faster than simply concatenating the arrays and calling sort on it.

We take advantage of the nature of this process to generate add events as ranges.

items.name: sum
items.text: Sums property values from some or all of the items in this collection.

items.name: property
items.text: The name of the property to sum from each item.

items.name: begin
items.text: The index of the first item to include in the sum.

items.name: end
items.text: The index at which to stop summing items. The item at this index will *not* be included in the sum.

The result of summing the specified property from the indicated
items.

items.name: sumByGroup
items.text: See sum. The result is partitioned by group.

items.name: property
items.text: The name of the property to sum from each item.
The result of sum, partitioned by group. See aggregateByGroup.

items.name: suspendEvent
items.text: Suspends firing of the named event(s). After calling this method to suspend events, the events will no longer fire when requested to fire. **Note that if this is called multiple times for a certain event, the converse method resumeEvent will have to be called the same number of times for it to resume firing.**

items.name: eventName
items.text: Multiple event names to suspend.

items.name: suspendEvents
items.text: Suspends the firing of all events. (see resumeEvents)

items.name: queueSuspended
items.text: `true` to queue up suspended events to be fired after the resumeEvents call instead of discarding all suspended events.

items.name: toLocaleString
items.text: Returns a string representing the object. This method is meant to be overridden by derived objects for locale-specific purposes. Objects toLocaleString returns the result of calling toString. This function is provided to give objects a generic toLocaleString method, even though not all may use it. Currently, only Array, Number, and Date override toLocaleString.
Object represented as a string.

items.name: toString

items.text: Object represented as a string.

items.name: un
items.text: Shorthand for removeListener.

items.name: unAfter
items.text: Removes a before-event handler. Same as removeListener with `order` set to `'after'`.

items.name: eventName
items.text: The name of the event the handler was associated with.

items.name: fn
items.text: The handler to remove.

items.name: scope
items.text: The scope originally specified for `fn`.

items.name: options
items.text: Extra options object.

items.name: unBefore
items.text: Removes a before-event handler. Same as removeListener with `order` set to `'before'`.

items.name: eventName
items.text: The name of the event the handler was associated with.

items.name: fn
items.text: The handler to remove.

items.name: scope
items.text: The scope originally specified for `fn`.

items.name: options
items.text: Extra options object.

items.name: update
fn
items.text: The function to call that will modify this collection.

items.name: collection
items.text: This collection.

items.name: scope
items.text: The `this` pointer to use when calling `fn`.
Returns the value returned from `fn` (typically undefined).

items.name: updateKey
items.text:
Change the key for an existing item in the collection. If the old key does not
exist this call does nothing. Even so, it is highly recommended to *avoid* calling
this method for an `item` that is not a member of this collection.

items.name: item
items.text:
The item whose key has changed. The `item` should be a member
of this collection.

items.name: oldKey
items.text: The old key for the `item`.

items.name: valueOf
items.text: Returns the primitive value of the specified object. JavaScript calls the valueOf method to convert an object to a primitive value. You rarely need to invoke the valueOf method yourself; JavaScript automatically invokes it when encountering an object where a primitive value is expected. By default, the valueOf method is inherited by every object descended from Object. Every built- in core object overrides this method to return an appropriate value. If an object has no primitive value, valueOf returns the object itself, which is displayed as: [object Object] You can use valueOf within your own code to convert a built-in object into a primitive value. When you create a custom object, you can override `Object.valueOf` to call a custom method instead of the default Object method. You can create a function to be called in place of the default valueOf method. Your function must take no arguments. Suppose you have an object type `myNumberType` and you want to create a valueOf method for it. The following code assigns a user-defined function to the object's valueOf method: myNumberType.prototype.valueOf = new Function(functionText) With the preceding code in place, any time an object of type `myNumberType` is used in a context where it is to be represented as a primitive value, JavaScript automatically calls the function defined in the preceding code. An object's valueOf method is usually invoked by JavaScript, but you can invoke it yourself as follows: myNumber.valueOf() Note: Objects in string contexts convert via the toString method, which is different from String objects converting to string primitives using valueOf. All objects have a string conversion, if only `"[object type]"`. But many objects do not convert to number, boolean, or function.
Returns value of the object or the object itself.

items.name: $endUpdatePriority
items.text:
Priority that is used for endupdate listeners on the filters and sorters.
set to a very high priority so that our processing of these events takes place prior
to user code - data must already be filtered/sorted when the user's handler runs

items.name: $eventOptions
items.text: Matches options property names within a listeners specification object  - property names which are never used as event names.

items.name: constructor
eventsSuspended
items.text: Initial suspended call count. Incremented when suspendEvents is called, decremented when resumeEvents is called.

items.name: filtered
items.text: A read-only flag indicating if this object is filtered.

items.name: generation
items.text: Mutation counter which is incremented when the collection changes.

items.name: grouped
items.text: A read-only flag indicating if this object is grouped.

items.name: hasListeners
items.text: This object holds a key for any event that has a listener. The listener may be set directly on the instance, or on its class or a super class (via observe) or on the Ext.app.EventBus. The values of this object are truthy (a non-zero number) and falsy (0 or undefined). They do not represent an exact count of listeners. The value for an event is truthy if the event must be fired and is falsy if there is no need to fire the event. The intended use of this property is to avoid the expense of fireEvent calls when there are no listeners. This can be particularly helpful when one would otherwise have to call fireEvent hundreds or thousands of times. It is used like this: if (this.hasListeners.foo) { this.fireEvent('foo', this, arg1); }

items.name: indexRebuilds
items.text: The number of times the indices have been rebuilt. This is for diagnostic use.

items.name: indices
items.text: An object used as map to get the index of an item.

items.name: isCollection
items.text:
`true` in this class to identify an object as an instantiated Collection, or subclass
thereof.

items.name: isObservable
items.text: `true` in this class to identify an object as an instantiated Observable, or subclass thereof.

items.name: items
items.text: An array containing the items.

items.name: length
items.text: The count of items in the collection.

items.name: map
items.text: An object used as a map to find items based on their key.

items.name: prototype
items.text: Allows the addition of properties to all objects of type Object.

items.name: sorted
items.text: A read-only flag indicating if this object is sorted. This flag may not be correct during an update of the sorter collection but will be correct before onSortChange is called. This flag is `true` if grouped is `true` because the collection is at least sorted by the grouper.

items.name: updating
items.text: A counter that is increased by beginUpdate and decreased by endUpdate. When this transitions from 0 to 1 the event-beginupdate event is fired. When it transitions back from 1 to 0 the event-endupdate event is fired.
